unnormalised: Planning a team meeting? Arriving late is a big no-no in most Indian offices, you know? Especially if the meeting's scheduled for, say, 10:00 AM sharp. Punctuality is key, my friend! So, when booking slots, consider everyone's schedule. We can use tools like Google Calendar or Microsoft Outlook. If someone from the Chennai branch needs to join, don't forget to convert it to their timezone. A meeting at 2:30 PM IST might be 12:00 PM GMT.
normalised: Planning a team meeting? Arriving late is a big no-no in most Indian offices, you know? Especially if the meeting's scheduled for, say, ten A M sharp. Punctuality is key, my friend! So, when booking slots, consider everyone's schedule. We can use tools like Google Calendar or Microsoft Outlook. If someone from the Chennai branch needs to join, don't forget to convert it to their timezone. A meeting at two thirty P M I S T might be twelve P M G M T.

unnormalised: Prepone or postpone? That's always the question! If something urgent pops up, it's okay to reschedule. But give everyone a heads-up, preferably 24 hrs in advance. A simple email or WhatsApp message will do. Maybe you planned a catch-up for 16/12/2024, but a project deadline shifted. Just say, "Hey, can we move our chat to 18/12/24 instead?"
normalised: Prepone or postpone? That's always the question! If something urgent pops up, it's okay to reschedule. But give everyone a heads-up, preferably twenty four hours in advance. A simple email or W-hats-A-p-p message will do. Maybe you planned a catch-up for sixteenth December two thousand and twenty four, but a project deadline shifted. Just say, "Hey, can we move our chat to eighteenth December two thousand and twenty four instead?"

unnormalised: And don't forget about holidays! Marking all public holidays, like Diwali on 01/11/2024 or Republic Day on 26/01/2025, on your calendar is crucial. Imagine scheduling a critical review on a day when everyone's with their families! Major blunder, right? Most companies even have restricted holidays for different communities, like Eid on 10/04/2024 (tentative).
normalised: And don't forget about holidays! Marking all public holidays, like Diwali on first November two thousand and twenty four or Republic Day on twenty sixth January two thousand and twenty five, on your calendar is crucial. Imagine scheduling a critical review on a day when everyone's with their families! Major blunder, right? Most companies even have restricted holidays for different communities, like Eid on tenth April two thousand and twenty four (tentative).

unnormalised: Lunch breaks, tea breaks – these are essential, especially for longer sessions. Keep meetings under 1 hr if possible, or plan a 10 min break midway. Nobody can concentrate for hours on end! A quick chai at 4:00 PM can do wonders. Also, try to avoid scheduling important discussions right before or after lunch (1:00 PM to 2:00 PM). Everyone's thinking about food then!
normalised: Lunch breaks, tea breaks – these are essential, especially for longer sessions. Keep meetings under one hour if possible, or plan a ten minute break midway. Nobody can concentrate for hours on end! A quick chai at four P M can do wonders. Also, try to avoid scheduling important discussions right before or after lunch (one P M to two P M). Everyone's thinking about food then!

unnormalised: Ultimately, effective work scheduling means being considerate. Think about weekends, religious observances, and travel times. Getting everyone on the same page from the get-go reduces confusion and keeps things running smoothly. Happy scheduling!
